TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit X509ExtensionCollection extends System.Object implements class System.Collections.ICollection, class System.Collections.IEnumerable

Docs.summary: Represents a collection of objects. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This class represents a collection of <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Extension> objects associated with a certificate. These extensions can provide additional information about the certificate.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is derived from the <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> interface and is overridden to always return `false`. For more information about this property, see the <xref:System.Collections.ICollection.IsSynchronized%2A> property of the <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> interface.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this property to get information about an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Extension> object when you know the object identifier (OID) of the extension in the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ExtensionCollection> object.

Docs.summary: Gets an object that you can use to synchronize access to the object.
Docs.value: An object that you can use to synchronize access to the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property implements the <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> interface. The .NET Framework classes based on <xref:System.Array> provide their own synchronized version of the collection using the SyncRoot property. Classes that use arrays can also implement their own synchronization using the SyncRoot property. The synchronizing code must perform operations on the SyncRoot property of the collection, not directly on the collection. This ensures proper operation of collections that are derived from other objects. Specifically, it maintains proper synchronization with other threads that might be simultaneously modifying the collection. Note that some implementations of SyncRoot might return the array itself.
Enumerating through a collection is intrinsically not a thread-safe procedure. Even when a collection is synchronized, other threads could still modify the collection, which causes the enumerator to throw an exception. To guarantee thread safety during enumeration, you can either lock the collection during the entire enumeration or catch the exceptions resulting from changes made by other threads.
